That's ok April - But I'm still happy to contribute to this test anyway I c=
an.
So if anyone would like to test their board, let's give it a try.


---=
 On Wed, 4/15/09, April Abercrombie <april@...> wr=
ote:

From: April Abercrombie <april@...>
Subject:=
 Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: An alternative to the usual ghost hunter stuff.
To: EVP-=
ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, April 15, 2009, 4:50 PM











   =
 
            
            


      
      =EF=BB=BF


Yes, I agree, we hav=
e to start 
somewhere.
=C2=A0
If I could, I would. But Hubby won't let me 
=
play with my Ouija board=C2=A0:(
=C2=A0

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  =
From: 
  Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
  Sent: Wednesday, April 15, 2=
009 5:39 
  PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: An alternative 
  to the usual =
ghost hunter stuff.
  

  
  
  
    
    
      
Just testing with me (my =
one lonely data point) is 
        not as subjective as one person asking t=
heir board open-ended questions, 
        but I agree it is also not as obj=
ective as it could be with more people, 
        or perhaps more randomized=
 data sources.

So while I still have my 
        one data point test open =
to anyone who would like to test their board, 
        we can also add futu=
re tests, with other people, or other "answer" 
        sources.=C2=A0 That=
 would add to the reliability of the performance 
        statistics, while=
 collecting more data.

But I think it's best to 
        do one test at a =
time, yes?=C2=A0 So, might as well begin with mine, for 
        those who =
are so inclined to begin testing, and then see where we go 
        from th=
ere.

--- On Wed, 4/15/09, April Abercrombie 
        <april@abercrombiegh =
ostresearch. com> 
        wrote:

        
From: 
          April Abercrom=
bie 
          <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
Subject: Re: 
       =

To: 
     =

Date: Wednesday, April 15, 2009, 4:18 
      =
    PM


          
          
          =EF=BB=BF 
          "Asking the b=
oard open-ended questions, and interpreting the 
          results, is subj=
ective. Asking for a specific, predetermined number is 
          not subje=
ctive.=C2=A0 It is about as objective as you can get."
          =C2=A0
   =
       Your test is subjective in that it 
          is based on just your =
influence. Therefore, all we can test with it is 
          your influence =
on the board.=C2=A0Add a few more people to the study, 
          then we c=
an objectify it a little more.
          =C2=A0
          In the second par=
agraph, the test 
          you outlined with testing the 2 people, is not =
subjective, because you 
          have more then just one person. It would=
 even be better with a few 
          more test subjects.
          =C2=A0
=
          =C2=A0
          "My test is not for those who believe it is stat=
istically likely 
          that psychic tampering would occur, or that the=
 board=E2=80=99s performance is 
          just not testable, which is the =
camp I gather you are in."
          =C2=A0
          Not at all. I do not =
have any 
          opinion either way if the board can or can't be psychic=
ally influence, 
          because I do not know.=C2=A0I do think the board=
 can be tested for 
          certain things. I just don't think your test =
using just you would tell 
          us much in the grand scheme of things.=
 This is not meant to pick on 
          you in any way, I do think it=C2=
=A0the test you have proposed 
          would=C2=A0be interesting.
       =
   =C2=A0
          =C2=A0
          
            ----- 
            Origin=
al Message ----- 
            From: 
            Rj 
            To: 
     =
       EVP-ITC@yahoogroups 
            .com 
            Sent: 
          =
  Wednesday, April 15, 2009 4:57 PM
            Subject: 
            Re: [=
EVP-ITC] Re: An alternative to the usual ghost hunter 
            stuff.
 =
           

            
            
            
              
        =
      
                Asking the board open-ended questions, and 
        =
          interpreting the results, is subjective. Asking for a 
          =
        specific, predetermined number is not subjective.=C2=A0 It is 
    =
              about as objective as you can get. 

I am not trying to 
    =
              prove anything, or rule out any possibilities.=C2=A0 I am 
  =
                suggesting a method to determine, statistically, how accura=
te 
                  someone=E2=80=99s board, or methodology, might be.=C2=
=A0 Lets say I 
                  select two people, and in separate rooms,=
 I give each a 
                  spelling test.=C2=A0 Person 1 gets 100% r=
ight.=C2=A0 Person 2 
                  gets 50% right.=C2=A0 Now, if I lat=
er give them a second 
                  spelling test, I can start with th=
e theory that Person 1 will 
                  get near 100% correct, and P=
erson 2 will get near 50% 
                  correct.=C2=A0 This doesn=E2=
=80=99t mean they will, or that they have 
                  gotten these s=
cores in the past.=C2=A0 But statistically, it 
                  is a reas=
onable assumption at this point.=C2=A0 After the 
                  second =
test, I can examine the deviation of the results from 
                  th=
e first test, and update the statistics.=C2=A0=C2=A0 If the 
              =
    deviation remains small (if the results remain similar), then 
        =
          I can more and more safely assume that person 1 will have a 
    =
              very high chance of getting a word right, and person 2 will 
=
                  have half that.=C2=A0 If the deviation swings wildly, tha=
n my 
                  statistics may not be very predictive after all.

T=
he 
                  same is true with the board.=C2=A0 As you said, getti=
ng this 
                  number wrong doesn=E2=80=99t say past answers we=
re wrong, or that 
                  future answers will be wrong.=C2=A0 An=
d it is possible it 
                  could have been right by mere chance=
 (though very unlikely: 
                  winning the lottery is more like=
ly than guessing one number 
                  out of a billion).=C2=A0 Wha=
t we=E2=80=99d have is one single 
                  objective data point.=
=C2=A0 It gives a starting point for 
                  reasonable assumpti=
ons.=C2=A0 As you noted, after more such 
                  tests, those as=
sumptions may start changing.=C2=A0 It would be 
                  interest=
ing to see how they change, if they 
                  do.

Different peopl=
e seem to have different feelings 
                  about the board.=C2=A0=
 Some believe it gives great 
                  results.=C2=A0 Some are sus=
picious, even dubious.=C2=A0 And 
                  there are plenty of opi=
nions in between.=C2=A0 My test is not 
                  for those who bel=
ieve it is statistically likely that psychic 
                  tampering w=
ould occur, or that the board=E2=80=99s performance is just 
              =
    not testable, which is the camp I gather you are in.=C2=A0 My 
        =
          test is only good for that segment of this population who 
      =
            believes or wonders if the board is capable of giving a 
      =
            straight objective answer to a straight objective questions, 
 =
                 and that such performance is testable.=C2=A0 To address on=
e of 
                  your examples, while it cannot show that an entity =
is reading 
                  my mind if it gets the numbers right, it can =
conversely show 
                  that an actual entity is not reading my =
mind (or that it is 
                  not performing remote viewing, or th=
at it is not predicting 
                  the future of what the right ans=
wer is when it is revealed, or 
                  that it is not being fort=
hright in its answers) if it cannot 
                  get the numbers righ=
t in the first place.=C2=A0 But if these 
                  things are true=
, then it begs the question of its accuracy 
                  anyway.

So =
again, this is one data point, in what could 
                  be a number=
 of tests, for those who are not ruling out that 
                  testing=
 is possible, and even desirable, when believing, or 
                  act=
ing on, information gathered by using this kind of 
                  board=
.=C2=A0

ature by

ould not mean that it couldn't get

er or that someone else couldn't

uld also not mean that=C2=A0answers it

he past weren't correct,=C2=A0coming from a

ng or a spirit.=C2=A0 It would not prove anything,

ept that it was not acting on any psychic vibrations from 
                =
    you personally.
                    =C2=A0
                    If it go=
t your number 
                    correct, that doesn't even help immediat=
ely, because it 
                    could get the answer on mere chance.
 =
                   =C2=A0
                    The only way to prove 
      =
              here that it is being psychically influenced would be to run =

                    several tests of the same nature. Then, if it scored c=
orrect 
                    higher then mere chance, only then could you sa=
y that the 
                    board can be psychically tampered with.=C2=
=A0Still, that is 
                    the only thing you could say for cer=
tain. That would 
                    not=C2=A0rule=C2=A0out the possibilit=
y that spirits can 
                    communicate through it.
           =
         =C2=A0
                    =C2=A0So we would be 
                 =
   left with=C2=A0more questions. Is it that it is being 
                 =
   psychically tampered with by a human mind directly? Is it 
             =
       and actual entity reading someone's mind? Can it be 
               =
     both?
                    =C2=A0
                    See what I am 
  =
                  sayin'?
                    =C2=A0
                    =
=C2=A0

 =

                <td valign=3D"top">Asking the board open-=
ended questions, and 
                  interpreting the results, is subjec=
tive. Asking for a 
                  specific, predetermined number is not=
 subjective.  It is 
                  about as objective as you can g=
et. <br><br>I am not trying to 
                  prove anything, or rule o=
ut any possibilities.  I am 
                  suggesting a method to =
determine, statistically, how accurate 
                  someone=E2=80=99s=
 board, or methodology, might be.  Lets say I 
                  selec=
t two people, and in separate rooms, I give each a 
                  spell=
ing test.  Person 1 gets 100% right.  Person 2 
                 =
 gets 50% right.  Now, if I later give them a second 
                =
  spelling test, I can start with the theory that Person 1 will 
          =
        get near 100% correct, and Person 2 will get near 50% 
            =
      correct.  This doesn=E2=80=99t mean they will, or that they have=
 
                  gotten these scores in the past.  But statisticall=
y, it 
                  is a reasonable assumption at this point.  Af=
ter the 
                  second test, I can examine the deviation of the =
results from 
                  the first test, and update the statistics.&=
nbsp;  If the 
                  deviation remains small (if the resul=
ts remain similar), then 
                  I can more and more safely assu=
me that person 1 will have a 
                  very high chance of getting=
 a word right, and person 2 will 
                  have half that.  I=
f the deviation swings wildly, than my 
                  statistics may no=
t be very predictive after all.<br><br>The 
                  same is true =
with the board.  As you said, getting this 
                  number w=
rong doesn=E2=80=99t say past answers were wrong, or that 
                =
  future answers will be wrong.  And it is possible it 
              =
    could have been right by mere chance (though very unlikely: 
          =
        winning the lottery is more likely than guessing one number 
      =
            out of a billion).  What we=E2=80=99d have is one single 
=
                  objective data point.  It gives a starting point for=
 
                  reasonable assumptions.  As you noted, after more =
such 
                  tests, those assumptions may start changing.  =
It would be 
                  interesting to see how they change, if they =

                  do.<br><br>Different people seem to have different feeli=
ngs 
                  about the board.  Some believe it gives great 
=
                  results.  Some are suspicious, even dubious.  A=
nd 
                  there are plenty of opinions in between.  My tes=
t is not 
                  for those who believe it is statistically likel=
y that psychic 
                  tampering would occur, or that the board=
=E2=80=99s performance is just 
                  not testable, which is th=
e camp I gather you are in.  My 
                  test is only good f=
or that segment of this population who 
                  believes or wonde=
rs if the board is capable of giving a 
                  straight objectiv=
e answer to a straight objective questions, 
                  and that suc=
h performance is testable.  To address one of 
                  your =
examples, while it cannot show that an entity is reading 
                 =
 my mind if it gets the numbers right, it can conversely show 
            =
      that an actual entity is not reading my mind (or that it is 
        =
          not performing remote viewing, or that it is not predicting 
    =
              the future of what the right answer is when it is revealed, o=
r 
                  that it is not being forthright in its answers) if it =
cannot 
                  get the numbers right in the first place.  B=
ut if these 
                  things are true, then it begs the question o=
f its accuracy 
                  anyway.<br><br>So again, this is one data=
 point, in what could 
                  be a number of tests, for those wh=
o are not ruling out that

desirable, when believing, or

hered by using this kind of
